body_html:
I'm sorry - but this code looks pretty confused to me. As @sherrym said above, the android example is expecting a graphdef with a placeholder node called 'input' into which it will presumably feed images from the camera. Your original code had an unused placeholder node called input_placeholder:

input_data = tf.placeholder(tf.float32,shape=[1,24,24,3], name="input_placeholder")

The new code above calls cifar10.distorted_inputs() which I believe generates a graph to read input images from files in the filesystem (whose names are retrieved from a queue!) and randomly mutates them. If you want this to work you will need to create a graphdef which accepts images via a node called 'input' and feeds them into cifar10.inference.

Since it isn't a TensorFlow bug, but really a general programming question, you should probably re-ask this on StackOverflow. (please ensure you tag the question 'tensorflow').

input_data = tf.placeholder(tf.float32,shape=[1,24,24,3], name="input_placeholder")

The new code above calls cifar10.distorted_inputs() which I believe generates a graph to read input images from files in the filesystem (whose names are retrieved from a queue!) and randomly mutates them.  If you want this to work you will need to create a graphdef which accepts images via a node called 'input' and feeds them into cifar10.inference.

body:
I'm sorry - but this code looks pretty confused to me.  As @sherrym said above, the android example is expecting a graphdef with a placeholder node called 'input' into which it will presumably feed images from the camera.  Your _original_ code had an _unused_ placeholder node called `input_placeholder`: 

```
input_data = tf.placeholder(tf.float32,shape=[1,24,24,3], name="input_placeholder")
```

The _new_ code above calls cifar10.distorted_inputs() which I believe generates a graph to read input images from files in the filesystem (whose names are retrieved from a queue!) and randomly mutates them.  If you want this to work you will need to create a graphdef which accepts images via a node called 'input' and feeds them into cifar10.inference. 

Since it isn't a TensorFlow bug, but really a general programming question, you should probably re-ask this on StackOverflow. (please ensure you tag the question 'tensorflow').
